Allen Ginsberg.Action: Stares defiantly at Lucien after Lucien forbids him from showing the manuscript
Snatches the manuscript back from Lucien in a tug of war, defies Lucien's pleas and leaves prison abruptly.
Switches the radio station from a somber war broadcast to an upbeat boogie-woogie number and dances joyfully with a broom.
Snatches his manuscript back from Lucien and wins the tug of war, demonstrating determination and physical assertiveness.
Turns and races toward the prison exit despite Lucien's alarm and warnings, showing decisive action and confidence.
Does not turn back when Lucien pleads, illustrating focus and resolve but possibly recklessness.
Smiles and dances joyfully alone to upbeat music while cleaning, reflecting a lighthearted, confident approach to daily tasks.
Groans at the war news on the radio before decisively changing the station, demonstrating awareness and preference for control over his environment.
Turns up the phonograph volume to drown out distressing sounds, helps soothe Naomi by encouraging a shared moment of calm with music and a waltz.
Hides the fact that he applied to Columbia University from his mother, revealing hesitation and lack of openness.
Responds thoughtfully with his father Louis in a poetic exchange, showing intelligence and emotional awareness.
Appears ashamed and caught when Louis confronts him, indicating insecurity and discomfort.
Receives and confidently announces acceptance to Columbia University, embraces his father in celebration.
Studies the NYC subway map intently, shows curiosity and an eagerness to navigate his new environment.
Appears in awe and somewhat overwhelmed by the grandeur of Columbia and the library setting.
Seemingly naive to warnings about Greenwich Village from his roommate.
Grins to himself and feels amused by Lucien Carr’s rebellious recitation and antics, rather than chastising or distancing himself from the disruption.
Challenges the professor respectfully by raising his hand and citing Whitman as a counterexample.
Responds honestly and self-deprecatingly when asked about his father's poetry style, saying it's easier.
Does not retaliate or escalate when the professor traps him in an argument, but quietly accepts the loss and sighs, showing tolerance and humility.
Refuses to go to the social despite encouragement, citing responsibility and workload.
Mesmerized by Lucien's talk and the book, showing openness and curiosity.
Reluctantly hands back the book and answers phone call, showing some distance or distraction.
Quickly grasps and explains the literary concept of consonance and reiteration of themes when discussing Yeats' complex idea, surprising Lucien.
Claims he is not a writer despite showing insight and interest in literature.
Momentarily distracted and unresponsive when called by the Hall Monitor, indicating a lapse in attention.
Handles the phone call professionally after snapping out of his distraction.
Shows concern for his mother Naomi, promising to come home as soon as he can despite the pull to join Lucien.
Hangs up abruptly on his mother but follows through on his promise by racing after Lucien, showing sincerity and commitment.
Interacts with Lucien in a friendly, warm manner, responding to his invitation and following him into the city.
Correctly identifies Ogden Nash and provides accurate information, showing literary knowledge.
Engages thoughtfully in the discussion about poetic movements and proposes new ideas like 'New Vision,' demonstrating creative intelligence and enthusiasm.
Appears captivated and swept up by Lucien's passion without challenging or critically assessing the ideas deeply, showing some passivity.
Pulls Naomi back into the house, refuses to let her leave, and shoves the nurse off her in an attempt to protect her.
Breaks down emotionally after Naomi is taken away, showing deep emotional vulnerability and care.
Shares a moment of understanding and solidarity with Lucien, empathizing with his pain.
Contemplates suicide, expressing that he has been making other people happy at the cost of himself.
Pushing Allen to finish the whole drink with Benzedrine and coffee; furiously typing manifesto; engaging excitedly with Lucien and Bill
Stops Lucien in his tracks and sincerely compliments him by saying 'You are an extraordinary man.'
Struggles to his feet, moaning and scared, then stumbles out of the room when David orders to leave.
Allowing David and Lucien to have a private moment while he splashes water on his face, observing quietly.
Continues searching for inspiration and beauty in his writing despite mental block.
Takes drugs to enhance productivity after encouragement from Bill.
Becomes furious at Luke's interruption while in an erratic state.
Defensively pockets his poem when Lucien asks about it.
Questions Lucien earnestly about what makes Jack a real writer, indicating curiosity and desire to learn.
Shakes head and refuses to catch the football, avoiding playful engagement.
Critiques Jack's manuscript for missing punctuation, showing attention to detail and literary insight.
Engages in minor argument about writing style with Lucien, showing some insecurity but also confidence in his own method.
Reluctantly joins Jack and Lucien in chasing after the dingy despite feeling like a third wheel.
Looks to Lucien for help during the exchange, showing a desire to connect and be part of the conversation.
Uses sarcasm and harsh language ('Fuck you', 'Fuck your one million words') during the exchange.
Shares his poem openly with Jack and Lucien by pulling it out of his pocket.
Engages in spirited verbal sparring but challenges others rather than being openly supportive.
Reluctantly chases after Lucien and Jack, showing lack of initiative.
Uses sarcasm and defensive language when challenged, indicating discomfort in confrontation.
Looks to Lucien for help when pressured, shows dependence on others for support.
Engages in verbal sparring with Jack, countering arguments with sharp retorts.
Pulls out his poem confidently when challenged, asserting his identity as a writer.
Reads a vulnerable, sincere poem about love, suffering, and sharing, which moves others deeply.
Sits back down completely vulnerable after sharing emotional poetry.
Engages emotionally with peers and responds humbly when complimented.
Listens nervously outside the dean's office showing concern for a friend.
Writes and reads a deeply personal and insightful poem that moves those around him, showing emotional intelligence and self-expression.
Points out practical weaknesses in the plan (e.g., Lucien not speaking French).
Sits back down, vulnerable and silent after sharing the poem, showing emotional openness but perhaps social passivity.
Is nervous waiting outside the dean’s office and leans in to listen to the reprimand, suggesting anxiety and lack of assertiveness.
Responds to Edith's nervous introduction with a smirk and a sarcastic comment about his mother.
Inquires about Edith's presence but does not engage to comfort or ease her nervousness.
Grabs Lucien's suitcase and sits beside him, sharing his personal struggles and encouraging Lucien to take action together.
Defies his father by admitting he stole the boat, expressing honesty and courage.
Grins and proposes payback to Lucien, showing camaraderie and inclusive spirit.
Smiles nervously and politely asks Gwendolyn for help finding a book.
Persists courteously in asking for the book despite the rules.
Volunteers to take over a failed plan, shows initiative to keep the plan going.
Approaches the permissions desk nervously but confidently asks for help finding a book.
Persists gently when initially denied access to the book, demonstrating interpersonal skill and tact.
Relies on others (Lucien, Gwendolyn) to facilitate access, shows ability to work collaboratively.
Stops Gwendolyn from pawing his pants and undoes her sweater, showing personal boundaries despite awkwardness.
Takes off Gwendolyn's sweater when she encourages him, responding to her initiative despite discomfort.
Realizes Gwendolyn has keys she shouldn't have and decides to intervene by telling her to take off her cardigan, enabling Lucien to retrieve the keys.
Reluctantly participates in an intimate act despite discomfort.
Responds sincerely when accused of not reading books.
Passively accepts Lucien's watching and involvement during the sexual encounter without protest.
Partners with friends in sneaky library break-in, cooperating quietly and carefully with peers.
Reluctantly participates in a sexual act but maintains composure and attempts to assert himself verbally afterward.
Maintains eye contact and focus during an uncomfortable situation, showing internal confidence.
Follows through with plans to enter the library stealthily and work with others during the break-in attempt.
Fails to stop Gwendolyn from initiating the sexual act despite initial resistance, showing some passivity.
Lifts pants and ties belt after the event, preparing himself calmly, demonstrating practical awareness.
Getting locked inside due to chewing gum failing to hold door properly, signaling a miscalculation or lack of foresight.
Acts decisively to help Lucien escape by flipping all the switches to cause a blinding flash and then plunging the room into darkness to enable their getaway.
Blocks the library doors with his shoulder to protect Lucien and buy time until help arrives.
Leans over the table and inserts himself into the conversation about the term paper, showing engagement and willingness to participate intellectually.
Reacted with a casual and somewhat dismissive comment towards David's presence and intentions ('Maybe he didn't want to see you').
Glances suspiciously with Jack and Bill at David, then guesses David betrayed them.
Says to Lucien 'Cut him off' to stop David from escalating conflict.
Sits quietly at a library after breaking in and robbing it; struggles emotionally and breaks down in tears while typing Lucien's name.
Writes a paper for Lucien and offers it along with an apology, demonstrating a conciliatory and considerate behavior.
Expresses hurt and frustration with Lucien silently departing and not telling him, culminating in an angry outburst calling Lucien a 'phony.'
Walks into the bar where he first drank with Lucien, despite being wrecked and terrified, and confidently asks for a whiskey.
Races toward a young man in a Merchant Marine outfit hoping it is Lucien, but immediately recognizes the man is a stranger, showing perceptiveness.
Sits down looking terrified when first confronted by an older man in the bar, showing a lack of confidence.
Turns to face the sailor and looks him in the eye, then reaches to kiss the sailor.
Alone in the shower, blank, reflecting on the previous night and realizing who he is.
Steps out to see police and detectives whispering about Lucien's stabbing and expresses concern by making his way down the hall asking about what happened.
Calls Edie urgently to get information about Jack's arrest, showing concern and taking initiative.
Visits Lucien in jail despite feeling skeptical and shocked, demonstrating loyalty and willingness to face uncomfortable truths.
Questions Lucien harshly and expresses disbelief ('How could you?'), indicating a moment of judgment and potential lack of immediate empathy.
Looks away, realizing potential complicity, showing self-awareness and internal conflict, which suggests sincerity.
Quickly makes a decision to call Edie when he hears troubling news; actively seeks information about Jack's situation.
Visits Lucien in The Tombs despite the intimidating and bleak environment, showing resolve and commitment.
Expresses skepticism towards Lucien's story, trying to understand the situation clearly.
Looks away, potentially feeling complicit, indicating some internal conflict and lack of confidence in action.
Searches David's apartment carefully for clues about his past, shows reverence by un-suturing and restoring books to original condition
Quietly reflects and respects memories without disturbance, showing sensitivity to the space and its history
Carefully examines personal and emotional items related to Lucien and David, processing the significance sensitively.
Reunites with his mother Naomi after a long estrangement, allowing himself to melt in her arms and engage in heartfelt conversation.
Comforts his mother, reassuring her gently when she expresses fear and loneliness.
Admits being in over his head, confused and conflicted about helping a friend who killed a man.
Confides in his mother, showing vulnerability and trust.
Writes passionately about love and its permanence, showing emotional sincerity.
Defiantly confronts Lucien to reveal the truth, insisting on honesty.
Engages in a physical struggle with Lucien over the manuscript, showing desperation but also persistence.
Appears visibly nervous and unable to sit still while waiting to give deposition.
Leaves the District Attorney's office abruptly when called, avoiding immediate confrontation.
Refuses to retract his manuscript despite academic consequences and chooses to be expelled, showing confidence in his work and personal conviction.
Submits a manuscript that the Dean considers 'smutty and absurd,' indicating a possible lack of understanding of institutional expectations or social norms.
Reflects quietly and solemnly at the site of David's death, showing sensitivity and reverence.
Appears joyous and engaged in writing in his journal amidst a boisterous celebration, suggesting openness and emotional expressiveness.
Maintains a dressed-down, scruffy appearance rather than distancing himself socially, signaling authenticity and sincerity.
Silently observes historic moments with his father, showing reflective and connected behaviors without overt emotional display.
Observes and internalizes historic news with a calm, reflective demeanor, showing situational awareness and emotional intelligence.
Dresses scruffily and stays in the background in social settings, possibly indicating a lack of confidence or social assertiveness at this point.
Writes joyously in his journal during a moment of celebration, indicating self-expression and purposeful use of time.
Does not actively engage with the crowd or others during the bar celebration, showing a more passive presence.
Rushes upstairs immediately upon hearing his mother in distress, shows worry and dread on his face.
Moves towards his mother to console her, wraps her bleeding hand with a dish towel.
Tries to calm his mother, suggests she rest and clear her head, offers to send her back to Greystone.
Denies his father's claim that dad nailed windows, taking responsibility himself to protect his mother.
Turns on phonograph and increases volume to distract or calm mother during paranoid episode.
Turns up the music loudly to protect Naomi from hearing distressing sounds, then physically comforts her leading to a softened moment between them.

Introduces himself politely to new roommate, Luke Detweiler.

Grins to himself after Lucien's reckless outburst, showing amusement and curiosity rather than alarm.

Shows decisiveness and urgency by promising to come home soon and then quickly races after Lucien despite personal conflict.

Tries to make himself inconspicuous at a chaotic party, showing social awareness and caution.

Declines cannabis offered by Bill, expresses personal boundary respectfully.
Whispers a question about whether Bill is a criminal, showing curiosity but also cautiousness.

Declines cannabis; shows hesitation and cautiousness regarding drug use.
Questions if Bill is a criminal, indicating some social naivety or insecurity.
Observes details like the term paper, showing curiosity and attention.

Responds candidly to David's direct question, 'Why don't you like me?'

Responds positively and supportively to Lucien's energy and charm.

Engages in playful banter with Lucien, including correcting his speech and reacting to physical humor in their mock suicide scene.

After falling and nearly dying, breaks out into hysterical laughter, indicating difficulty managing a serious crisis.
Engages thoughtfully in intellectual discussion about the New Vision manifesto, actively contributing ideas.

Confronts Lucien at night, showing concern and desire for closeness.
Furious at interruption while writing, shows frustration but dedication.

Rips pages from the typewriter excitedly, indicating confidence and productivity.

Wakes up to Lucien entering late at night, expressing concern and curiosity.

Asks who the unfamiliar woman is, shows awareness of the situation, and maintains a smirk indicating some confidence.
Passively sits back and does not intervene or take any visible action during the confrontation between Lucien and the Dean.
Stares down his father and openly admits stealing the boat, showing courage and ownership.
Confesses being on academic probation and facing potential expulsion, revealing self-awareness but also a lack of control over academic responsibilities.
Encourages Lucien to join him in rebelling against their circumstances, demonstrating leadership and confidence.
Shows uncertainty about what to do next, indicating a lack of clear planning.

Unsutures pages of books and restores them, showing attention to detail and respect for the materials.

Admits he is in over his head and uncertain about how to handle a difficult moral situation involving a friend's crime.

Seeks guidance from his mother despite his struggles, showing some reliance on others rather than confident independent decision-making.
Calmly accepts the Dean's ultimatum and chooses to be expelled rather than retract his work.
Shares a quiet, warm moment of silent appreciation with his father Louis while writing poetry and smoking cigarettes together.
Became one of the most awarded poets in American history after expulsion from Columbia University.
Dedicated his first published collection Howl and Other Poems to Lucien Carr, who later asked for his name to be withdrawn.
